title: Week 5 Discussion Board Post (Section E)
message:
So this week again we have another example of the rather wide range of different kinds of story and different kinds of text that fall under this category of the “weird.”  This week we would seem to have a little bit of everything:  we have an absurdist tale of people who are forced to try to squeeze every last drop of liquid out of a really long towel/sheet (Sansom’s “The Long Sheet”)—a story that will easily remind many of Kafka’s “In the Penal Colony” (Week 3)—; we have a sample story from one of the greatest Latin American writers of the 20th Century, Jorge Luis Borges, whose “The Aleph” is a strange yarn about a spot in the universe from which one can simultaneously see every other single spot or space in the universe (bit of a mind-bender, that one); we have what looks like a good ol’ run of the mill ghost story in Bhêly-Quénum’s “A Child in the Bush of the Ghosts”; Shirley Jackson’s wonderful “The Summer People” is one of those eerie stories that probably everyone should read at some point (and I'm not sure if we have any fans of the TV show that Netflix made from one of her books, the rather famous The Haunting of Hill House [if any of you liked the TV version, the book version is even better, I would argue]); another story that links back—quite directly and explicitly—to the story by Lord Dunsany that we read in Week 2; Bloch’s “The Hungry House” which manages to combine a number of different scary, horror, fairy-tale like tropes and clichés in a way that produces something a little bit different; and it would be criminal not to mention Jerome Bixby's "It's A Good Life," which has been incredibly influential (the original Twilight Zone did a version of it in their 3rd season

and The Simpsons spoofed it in their second "Treehouse of Horror" episode back in [*gasp* I'm getting old] 1991.)

Last week I posed the possibility of thinking about how one could possibly compare one text to another (this week the Freud reading would seem to go extremely nicely with Bixby's story).  This week I’ll forgo putting forward a really explicit question and will let all of you dictate the conversation this week.

Options in terms of stories/authors:  Sansom, Borges, Bhely-Quenum, Jackson, St. Clair, Bloch, Jackson's "The Lottery," Tutuola, Bixby, and Monterroso (anything in between pages 290 and 351 is fair game).

all_dates.title: ENGL200F - Intro to Lit: Weird Fiction

title: Week 6 Discussion Board Post (Section E)
message:
Hi to all my weird readers—this week we have another nice heaping dose of weird fiction to work our way through.  Two stories stick out for me—both the Sansom (his work is just incredibly good—“The Long Sheet” from last week is brilliant and “A Women Seldom Found” is yet another gem); the second one I love is Dino Buzzati’s “The Colomber.”  Both stories seem to me to highlight a funny little “joke” that has been attributed to Oscar Wilde (in a short story from 1892) that goes as follows (perhaps you’ve seen it in meme form?):  “In this world there are only two tragedies.  One is not getting what one wants, and the other is getting it.  The last is much the worst, the last is a real tragedy!”

Buzzati’s “Colomber” strikes me as leaning on a technique that Franz Kafka was a master of—have a look at his short “Before the Law” story to get a look at the “ironic twist” similar to that used by Buzzati (Alessandro Novelli has also done an animated version of the Kafka story [while updating it a bit too—it’s worth a look if you have a free moment this week]). 

Of course, as always, do not feel the need to follow me down this road that looks just at the Buzzati and Sansome—take us wherever you would like!    

P.S.  If you really liked the Dino Buzzati, you just HAVE TO READ his 1966 weird short story, "The Falling Girl." If you're interested, here's a copy.  It's so bizarre I have a feeling everyone will dig it.  (It's super short and I cannot even begin to explain how good it is ... lol ...; now that I think about it I'm not quite sure why I didn't just officially assign it!)

Options for authors this week:  Cortazar, Sansom ("A Woman Seldom Found"), Beaumont, Peake, Buzzati, Bernanos, Rodoreda, Seignolle, and Wilson are all fair game.  

This time around:  give us your top three and also be sure to respond to another student's post.

all_dates.title: ENGL200F - Intro to Lit: Weird Fiction

title: Week 15 Discussion Board Post (Section E)
message:
Hi everyone,

So, for our very last discussion board assignment for this course (and I cannot even begin to tell you how much fun I have had reading and writing and talking with all of you in this class, it's crazy) I thought I would try yet another somewhat strange or "weird" question, perhaps. At the very end of the Weird anthology we've spent quite a bit of time together with here in this course, there is no index, only the list of "Extended Copyrights" on pages 1118-1126. An index—if you think about it for a little bit (and I'm not sure how many of you have really thought at all about them before)—is somewhat of a strange thing. They are ways to categorize things, to be sure—but why do we so often categorize things in the same old tired ways over and over again? So, in a book like this, one might expect to see an index that is just a list of authors' names and the page numbers their stories start on. Of course, this isn't the only way to categorize things—and I have a feeling that if we think a little bit about how we might want to try to "organize" all these stories in an index of some kind might be a little fun to think about.

An example: I'm not sure how many of you like to cook, but there seems to be a pretty "standard" way cookbooks are written. They are often split up into chapters based on the "kind" of dish it is (desserts, appetizers, drinks, etc.) and where exactly it fits into the order of a meal (appetizers come before main dishes, etc., etc., etc.). Indexes in cookbooks are often broken down by the name of the dish (alphabetically listed, of course)—but this isn't the only way, right? One could imagine a cookbook index being created according to the quantity of calories, or carbohydrates, or long it takes to make it, or whatever; one could imagine a cookbook index being ordered according to the ingredients; the possibilities are endless: how about a cookbook ordered according to the amount of CO2 required to create the dish and get it to your table (meat eaters here would probably be in a bit of trouble—producing steak is incredibly CO2-intensive—it takes so much CO2 to make even the smallest piece of steak,[1] but I digress); I could imagine a completely and totally unique and individualized cookbook that is organized according to my own likes and dislikes: I like pasta more than rice, egg noodles more than Udon, etc.

So, I pose the question: if I asked you to write an index for the Weird anthology, how would do it? What categories would you use? Would you group stories together in some way—how (you’ll notice too that sometimes indexes don’t really “group” anything together, they just list names)? Would you group them by how closely they resemble other genres, i.e. "horror," "detective fiction-type stories," "absurdist-y stories"? Would you group them according to how easy they are read (I can imagine this would work for the cookbook too:  "Dishes you can make in half-an-hour," "Dishes you really need a full day's worth of prep to make," etc.):  "Stories that are impossible to make sense of," "Stories I could kind of make sense of," what have you. Also, in your reply, if you could give all of us a couple examples of texts and which categories they fit into, that would be fantastic.  You obviously don't have to catalog all the stories in the anthology, but give us a few examples. (I hope that all makes sense; if not, feel free to just tell me it doesn't make any sense at all and I'll rework/rephrase it.) 

 

-----------------------------------------------------------

[1]  According to Alan Weisman’s math in Countdown:  Our Last, Best Hope for A Future on Earth? (New York:  Little, Brown and Co, 2013)—a book that I cannot recommend more highly to literally everyone on the planet—:  “… producing a kilogram of beef emits as much carbon dioxide as an average car driving 160 miles, and uses ten times the water as a kilo of wheat” (p. 41).

assignment.name: Week 15 Discussion Board Post (Section F)

all_dates.title: ENGL200F - Intro to Lit: Weird Fiction

title: Week 1 Discussion Board Post (Section D)
message:
Hi everyone,

So, this first week we’re spending quite a bit of time thinking through some terminology and some ways to theorize this thing called weird fiction.  I put up three different reading options here for how to think about weirdness.  Given that you won’t really be able to read all three of them, I’ll give some short-ish summaries here:

1.) From the thought of H. P. Lovecraft:  “weirdness” comes from a focus on “fear,” one of the most primordial of emotions.  Thinking about the stories we’ll read this semester in terms of “fear” will get us focusing on some things rather than others—and as we go through the semester feel free to decide if stories that make you afraid are best classified as “weird.”  Maybe, maybe not:  and why not call fiction that makes you afraid something like “horror” rather than “weird”? 

2.) From Freud and psychoanalysis:  here we have this notion of what Freud calls the “uncanny”—this is a feeling or affect that is strongly connected to repetition and things that repeat (Tyson does a wonderful job of explicating this).  Freud gives numerous examples of situations that produce uncanniness.  One of his most vivid is of his situation of getting lost in Rome and, while trying to find his bearings, he finds himself again and again and again coming back to the same place in the city.  It weirds him out, greatly.  Tyson helpfully shows many of the ways in which each of us is a kind of place or site of uncanniness:  when people finds themselves repeating the same actions again and again and again (I can’t seem to choose life partners that treat me well; I always find myself in the same situation over and over again with every lover/partner I have), this tips us off to the ways in which it is incredibly difficult for us to feel “at home in the world.”  Focusing on this angle will ask everyone to pay attention to repetition in these stories—how does repetition make certain things produce a feeling of weirdness or strangeness?    

3.) Lastly, we have Mark Fisher’s The Weird and the Eerie.  This book with its two chapters on the “weird” and the “eerie” give us a nice pair of definitions.  For Fisher, the “weird” is produced by the presence of something that shouldn’t really be there—weirdness occurs when two things come together that we don’t ever really normally think of as going together. (Fisher’s favorite example here is that of something like surrealist art, especially the strange ways in which Salvador Dali and so many others would put together all kinds of bizarre things that don’t normally go together at all.)  Perhaps an example?

I know this image by Rene Magritte from 1928 might seem strange to all of us post-COVID here, but this painting is called The Lovers.  A pair of lovers kissing with sheets over their faces should no doubt strike as a bit odd, no doubt?  When two kiss, we want nothing in between, nothing that closes off one to another.  It’s bizarre, to say the least.  Fisher says paintings like this are weird. 

Now “the eerie” is different.  Fisher argues that “the weird is constituted by a presence—the presence of that which does not belong. In some cases of the weird (those with which Lovecraft was obsessed) the weird is marked by an exorbitant presence, a teeming which exceeds our capacity to represent it. The eerie, by contrast, is constituted by a failure of absence or by a failure of presence. The sensation of the eerie occurs either when there is something present where there should be nothing, or there is [sic] nothing present when there should be something" (p. 27)  Fisher goes on to give us some examples: 

We can grasp these two modes quickly by means of examples. The notion of an “eerie cry” — often cited in dictionary definitions of the eerie — is an example of the first mode of the eerie (the failure of absence). A bird’s cry is eerie if there is a feeling that there is something more in (or behind) the cry than a mere animal reflex or biological mechanism — that there is some kind of intent at work, a form of intent that we do not usually associate with a bird. Clearly, there is something in common between this and the feeling of “something which does not belong” that we have said constitutes the weird. But the eerie necessarily involves forms of speculation and suspense that are not an essential feature of the weird. Is there something anomalous about this bird’s cry? What exactly is strange about it? Is, perhaps, the bird possessed — and if it is, by what kind of entity? Such speculations are intrinsic to the eerie, and once the questions and enigmas are resolved, the eerie immediately dissipates. The eerie concerns the unknown; when knowledge is achieved, the eerie disappears. It must be stressed at this point that not all mysteries generate the eerie. There must be also be a sense of alterity, a feeling that the enigma might involve forms of knowledge, subjectivity and sensation that lie beyond common experience. (p. 27)

Thus, the weird and the eerie, for Fisher, are not at all the same—and I myself will say that hopefully this distinction will be incredibly useful to all of us as we start making our way through the stories this semester. 

In terms of your response for this week, which two options did you take for this week and what did you think?  Did my summaries above leave too much out?  Is there something from these different readings that you found to be incredibly interesting or thought-provoking or confusing or impossible to understand or so crystal-clear that it wasn’t even funny?  Feel free to respond however you like and also to have a read through of your fellow students’ posts and respond if there was anything you saw that you liked, would like to expand upon, etc.  (If you wanted some  more long-winded guidelines from me for engaging the Lovecraft and Freud, more specifically, head over this way ...)

Choices of authors here to post about include Moorcock's "Foreweird," the Vandermeers's "Introduction," Lovecraft's "Supernatural Horror" or "Notes on Writing Weird Fiction," Freud's "The Uncanny," Tyson's chapter in Critical Theory Today, Fisher's The Weird and the Eerie.  

If you could, please respond to one of your fellow student's posts here for this week.  (You will all no doubt notice a pattern here very soon:  every week you will post your thoughts and reading of three stories from the assigned reading for the week (I've put the choices that you could pick for each week too on the prompt too, so you won't have to keep track of that)—and each week's board will also ask you to respond to one of your another post by one of your fellow students.  You're in the driver's seat:  you decide which three stories to focus on; you decide which of your fellow students' posts you would like to respond to each week.)

Lastly:  as a general guide, please feel free to cite the texts you discuss directly—the more often the better, although, use your judgment in how often you want to point us directly to a particular passage or sentence or what have you in the readings.

message: Hello everyone, so take a quick moment here this week and introduce yourself to everyone in the course—what you're studying, weird personality quirks (j/k—actually. share if you like), maybe something about your background with literature in general (what kinds of genres do you like to read), or perhaps just give us some idea of what you might hope to learn after doing this course on a genre of literature that might strike you as strange (or that perhaps you may not have even known actually existed):  "weird fiction."  (This last one, thinking about precisely what you might hope to learn in this course is an important one:  remember what answer you come up with because we're going to use it at the end of the semester to decide how you would like to assess what you've learned.)

title: Week 2 Discussion Board Post (Section D)
message:
Hi, everyone, so this week we have a large sample of stories that you could pick out for close inspection.  It will be more than fine for everyone to select which three stories they found to be most interesting or intriguing.  I myself am fond of the incredibly strange story, "Sredni Vashtar" by Saki.  It's bizarre and Conradin reminds me a bit of Sid in the first Toy Story film by Pixar (everybody remember him?).  Lord Dunsany's "How Nuth Would Have Practiced His Art Upon the Gnoles" has a title that seems almost as long as the story itself—it's a strange story, but it didn't (and still doesn't really "weird me out," as the saying go).  

Micahael Moorcock, in his "Foreweird" to our anthology, mentions a couple of qualities of "weird fiction," at least as far as his own personal definitions go.  One is "that they [these stories in the anthology] leave you with many more questions than answers ..." (p. xii); a second is that "the appeal of the weird story is precisely that is designed to disturb" (p. xiii).  The Saki story leaves me with some questions, yes:  is this ferret really a god after all? what does it mean for the narrator to tell us that when Conradin prays to his god in the hopes that he escapes from Mrs. De Ropp the following:  "But he knew as he prayed that he did not believe" (p. 55)?  Is this a real sign that the ferret is a god—i.e. precisely because in order for a god to be real it's totally irrelevant if one believes in him or her or not?  Dunsany's little tale strikes me as a bit disturbing, but it didn't leave me with tons of questions.  

That being, perhaps stories that do both at the same time are in some sense "better" than others that only do one of the two:  Meyrink's "The Man in the Bottle" would work and Ewers's "The Spider" is incredibly well-composed and well-written.  It's incredibly odd and creepy--not least of all because it honestly poses the possibility that, as Freud famously said (and those of you who are psychology students will know this):  "the ego is not the master in its own house," i.e. there are forces within me that aren't me ... there are things we compulsively do again and again that we do not consciously control, much like all the characters in the story.  There's even a kind of "death drive" (a la Freud) in the story too:  all the characters compulsively engage in these same actions that lead to their deaths.  As I say, it's an admittedly strange story.  

So, what do you all think?  Feel free to riff off of these remarks if any of them strike you as useful.  If not, skip them and go your own way!  

(There are as many different ways to "respond" to a text as there are readers in the world.  For those that might want it, here is a list of possibilities that are by no means exhaustive.  You could—when discussing the stories—:

  1. Focus on how the story "works":  if it weirds you out, what and how does it weird you out?  Is it just the content that weirds us, is it something about how the content is given that strikes you as strange?  [The more specific the better—and, if possible, parenthetically citing the story directly is always the way to go.]
  2. Focus on what does or does not "work" for you as reader:  which parts strike you as interesting, which parts are perhaps dull and just don't work at all.
  3. Make connections between the story and other stories in the texts—or, even better, stories or films or TV shows or YouTube memes or whatever.  The more connections you can make between texts and stories the better.  If there is a "rule" or guideline here, it would be something:  "Link up stories and texts together; I won't tell you how  to link things up, but do link them up."

As I say, not an exhaustive list by any stretch of the imagination, but hopefully it helps a little bit.)

Choices of authors/stories you could post about include:  Kubin, Blackwood, Saki (and/or Neato), James, Dunsay, Meyrink, Heym, Ewers, Tagore, Ugolini, Merritt (anything between pages 1 and 109 is fair game this week).  

Also, please do not forget to post a response to one of your fellow students' posts.

all_dates.title: ENGL200D - Intro to Lit: Weird Fiction

title: Week 3 Discussion Board Post (Section D)
message:
Hi everyone, so this week we are covering a couple of the greats, a couple of the true giants of the “weird” genre.  There are, to be sure, a number of really fantastic readings on the list for this week that one could really be interested in thinking about more extensively.  I would like to actually keep my comments rather sparse here at the start, as I’m really curious to see which stories everyone gravitates toward for this week’s reading.  There are certain figures, certain writers, certain artists, within genres that we often assume everyone will love (the memes could be right—although I for myself happen to really love the two giants [Lovecraft and Kafka] on the reading list for this week):

That being said, one should feel free enough to actually not like certain authors that other people claim everyone should like.  There are a couple authors on the list for this week that you are all supposed to absolutely love (according to some readers, not necessarily according to me); I’m curious if you all find those authors’ stories worth the hype, so to speak. 

Give us your top three stories—i.e. give us a write-up of all three—and why you liked them, how they worked (or didn't work for you), what jumped out to you in the stories, etc.  Also, don't forget to post a response to another student's post.  :-) 

Authors/stories you could discuss this week:  Akutagawa, Stevens, Kafka, Grabinski, Arnold, Lovecraft, Irwin, Ray, & Ray (anything b/t pages 110 and 222 of the anthology is fair game).

all_dates.title: ENGL200D - Intro to Lit: Weird Fiction

title: Week 4 Discussion Board Post (Section D)
message:
Hi everyone, so again this week we have a rather nice list of stories to sink our teeth into together.  There are a couple of names here that I will bet some have heard of before (Bruno Schulz is rather well-known in this genre and I would bet that a great many of you have probably heard of Ray Bradbury—perhaps because you read him in high school?).  That being said, I think there are some stories here by some other weird fiction writers for this week that are exceedingly good and probably ones many will never have heard of.  So, as an example, I would imagine that Leonora Carrington might be a new name for many (although I would hope art students—if we have any, I cannot remember!—would know her name)—and I think her little story “White Rabbits” (pp. 277-79) is quite bizarre.  Robert Barbour Johnson’s “Far Below” (260-67) is an intriguing test case as well. 

I think it could be a little premature, but I wonder if anyone can start to notice any differences between stories if we think about the historical span we’ve covered so far.  Thus, we started with a story by Alfred Kubin written in 1908 and the last story on the list for this week was written in the heart of WWII, Bradbury’s “The Crowd” (1943)—that’s almost an entire half-century—are the stories at the end of this range noticeably different those written in the early 1900s?  Or is it a bit too early to ask such a question? 

I also like the idea of someone who might suggest that asking such a question in the first place is a bit silly.  Is it really possible to "compare" literary texts across historical time?  Is one really comparing apples to apples or are we comparing apples to oranges?  Isn't each literary story radically and singularly itself and nothing else?  Aren't stories very much like people:  no two humans can be compared without remainder.  There's always something about each unique individual that will escape such comparisons.  Aren't stories the same, or no?  

Perhaps we're comparing different kinds of apples:  sure, there are "apples," but there are Gala apples, McIntosh, Granny Smith, Fuji, and the list goes on and on ... (for more apple stuff, lol, here).  If one takes into account the "fact" that there are "7,500 varieties of apples ... grown throughout the world" ("Apple Facts"), to say we're comparing "apples" to "apples" is really not all that helpful at the end of the day.  Such general concepts, like "apples," or literary genres like "weird fiction" may not be all that helpful or useful to think about things with ... ah, my apologies for rambling.  

Authors/stories up for discussion this week:  Smith, Sakutaro, Walpole, Schulz, Johnson, Leiber, Carrington, Wollheim, Bradbury (anything b/t pages 223 and 289).

all_dates.title: ENGL200D - Intro to Lit: Weird Fiction

title: Week 5 Discussion Board Post (Section D)
message:
So this week again we have another example of the rather wide range of different kinds of story and different kinds of text that fall under this category of the “weird.”  This week we would seem to have a little bit of everything:  we have an absurdist tale of people who are forced to try to squeeze every last drop of liquid out of a really long towel/sheet (Sansom’s “The Long Sheet”)—a story that will easily remind many of Kafka’s “In the Penal Colony” (Week 3)—; we have a sample story from one of the greatest Latin American writers of the 20th Century, Jorge Luis Borges, whose “The Aleph” is a strange yarn about a spot in the universe from which one can simultaneously see every other single spot or space in the universe (bit of a mind-bender, that one); we have what looks like a good ol’ run of the mill ghost story in Bhêly-Quénum’s “A Child in the Bush of the Ghosts”; Shirley Jackson’s wonderful “The Summer People” is one of those eerie stories that probably everyone should read at some point (and I'm not sure if we have any fans of the TV show that Netflix made from one of her books, the rather famous The Haunting of Hill House [if any of you liked the TV version, the book version is even better, I would argue]); another story that links back—quite directly and explicitly—to the story by Lord Dunsany that we read in Week 2; Bloch’s “The Hungry House” which manages to combine a number of different scary, horror, fairy-tale like tropes and clichés in a way that produces something a little bit different; and it would be criminal not to mention Jerome Bixby's "It's A Good Life," which has been incredibly influential (the original Twilight Zone did a version of it in their 3rd season

and The Simpsons spoofed it in their second "Treehouse of Horror" episode back in [*gasp* I'm getting old] 1991.)

Last week I posed the possibility of thinking about how one could possibly compare one text to another (this week the Freud reading would seem to go extremely nicely with Bixby's story).  This week I’ll forgo putting forward a really explicit question and will let all of you dictate the conversation this week.

Options in terms of stories/authors:  Sansom, Borges, Bhely-Quenum, Jackson, St. Clair, Bloch, Jackson's "The Lottery," Tutuola, Bixby, and Monterroso (anything in between pages 290 and 351 is fair game).

all_dates.title: ENGL200D - Intro to Lit: Weird Fiction

title: Week 6 Discussion Board Post (Section D)
message:
Hi to all my weird readers—this week we have another nice heaping dose of weird fiction to work our way through.  Two stories stick out for me—both the Sansom (his work is just incredibly good—“The Long Sheet” from last week is brilliant and “A Women Seldom Found” is yet another gem); the second one I love is Dino Buzzati’s “The Colomber.”  Both stories seem to me to highlight a funny little “joke” that has been attributed to Oscar Wilde (in a short story from 1892) that goes as follows (perhaps you’ve seen it in meme form?):  “In this world there are only two tragedies.  One is not getting what one wants, and the other is getting it.  The last is much the worst, the last is a real tragedy!”

Buzzati’s “Colomber” strikes me as leaning on a technique that Franz Kafka was a master of—have a look at his short “Before the Law” story to get a look at the “ironic twist” similar to that used by Buzzati (Alessandro Novelli has also done an animated version of the Kafka story [while updating it a bit too—it’s worth a look if you have a free moment this week]). 

Of course, as always, do not feel the need to follow me down this road that looks just at the Buzzati and Sansome—take us wherever you would like!    

P.S.  If you really liked the Dino Buzzati, you just HAVE TO READ his 1966 weird short story, "The Falling Girl." If you're interested, here's a copy.  It's so bizarre I have a feeling everyone will dig it.  (It's super short and I cannot even begin to explain how good it is ... lol ...; now that I think about it I'm not quite sure why I didn't just officially assign it!)

Options for authors this week:  Cortazar, Sansom ("A Woman Seldom Found"), Beaumont, Peake, Buzzati, Bernanos, Rodoreda, Seignolle, and Wilson are all fair game.  

This time around:  give us your top three and also be sure to respond to another student's post.

If you're interested, here's a copy.  It's so bizarre I have a feeling everyone will dig it.  (It's super short and I cannot even begin to explain how good it is ... lol ...; now that I think about it I'm not quite sure why I didn't just officially assign it!)

Options for authors this week:  Cortazar, Sansom ("A Woman Seldom Found"), Beaumont, Peake, Buzzati, Bernanos, Rodoreda, Seignolle, and Wilson are all fair game.  

This time around:  give us your top three and also be sure to respond to another student's post.

all_dates.title: ENGL200D - Intro to Lit: Weird Fiction

title: Week 15 Discussion Board Post (Section D)
message:
Hi everyone,

So, for our very last discussion board assignment for this course (and I cannot even begin to tell you how much fun I have had reading and writing and talking with all of you in this class, it's crazy) I thought I would try yet another somewhat strange or "weird" question, perhaps. At the very end of the Weird anthology we've spent quite a bit of time together with here in this course, there is no index, only the list of "Extended Copyrights" on pages 1118-1126. An index—if you think about it for a little bit (and I'm not sure how many of you have really thought at all about them before)—is somewhat of a strange thing. They are ways to categorize things, to be sure—but why do we so often categorize things in the same old tired ways over and over again? So, in a book like this, one might expect to see an index that is just a list of authors' names and the page numbers their stories start on. Of course, this isn't the only way to categorize things—and I have a feeling that if we think a little bit about how we might want to try to "organize" all these stories in an index of some kind might be a little fun to think about.

An example: I'm not sure how many of you like to cook, but there seems to be a pretty "standard" way cookbooks are written. They are often split up into chapters based on the "kind" of dish it is (desserts, appetizers, drinks, etc.) and where exactly it fits into the order of a meal (appetizers come before main dishes, etc., etc., etc.). Indexes in cookbooks are often broken down by the name of the dish (alphabetically listed, of course)—but this isn't the only way, right? One could imagine a cookbook index being created according to the quantity of calories, or carbohydrates, or long it takes to make it, or whatever; one could imagine a cookbook index being ordered according to the ingredients; the possibilities are endless: how about a cookbook ordered according to the amount of CO2 required to create the dish and get it to your table (meat eaters here would probably be in a bit of trouble—producing steak is incredibly CO2-intensive—it takes so much CO2 to make even the smallest piece of steak,[1] but I digress); I could imagine a completely and totally unique and individualized cookbook that is organized according to my own likes and dislikes: I like pasta more than rice, egg noodles more than Udon, etc.

So, I pose the question: if I asked you to write an index for the Weird anthology, how would do it? What categories would you use? Would you group stories together in some way—how (you’ll notice too that sometimes indexes don’t really “group” anything together, they just list names)? Would you group them by how closely they resemble other genres, i.e. "horror," "detective fiction-type stories," "absurdist-y stories"? Would you group them according to how easy they are read (I can imagine this would work for the cookbook too:  "Dishes you can make in half-an-hour," "Dishes you really need a full day's worth of prep to make," etc.):  "Stories that are impossible to make sense of," "Stories I could kind of make sense of," what have you. Also, in your reply, if you could give all of us a couple examples of texts and which categories they fit into, that would be fantastic.  You obviously don't have to catalog all the stories in the anthology, but give us a few examples. (I hope that all makes sense; if not, feel free to just tell me it doesn't make any sense at all and I'll rework/rephrase it.) 

 

-----------------------------------------------------------

[1]  According to Alan Weisman’s math in Countdown:  Our Last, Best Hope for A Future on Earth? (New York:  Little, Brown and Co, 2013)—a book that I cannot recommend more highly to literally everyone on the planet—:  “… producing a kilogram of beef emits as much carbon dioxide as an average car driving 160 miles, and uses ten times the water as a kilo of wheat” (p. 41).
